Award.AwardTitle: SCC-CIVIC-PG Track A: User-Centered Mobility Solutions (UCMS): A New Vision to Connect Jobs and the Labor Force

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration: A long-standing spatial mismatch has received significant attention between predominantly African American neighborhoods in the central city of Milwaukee and a large suburban employment center 15 miles northwest. Conventional fixed-route bus services were implemented but determined to be inefficient, so they were discontinued. Thus, the labor force (including employed workers and unemployed workers who are actively looking for jobs) and employers continue to struggle with the spatial mismatch. By adopting a fundamentally different approach that is bottom-up—focusing on the core users and their respective needs, this CIVIC Planning Grant (PG) will develop two pilot programs of User-Centered Mobility Solutions (UCMS), which integrate new mobility technologies, including transport network companies (TNCs) and micro-transit (e.g., Via), to directly address mobility needs of two types of core users—the labor force and employers. If successful, this project will serve as a new user-centered model for other U.S. metropolitan areas with significant spatial mismatches.<br/><br/>Initial PG activities will explore strategies that overcome communication and institutional barriers to formulate intra-region UCMS and to facilitate successful implementation. During this stage, the research team will connect with workforce development organizations and business organizations to recruit and engage core users, identify and address barriers, jointly select alternative mobility services with core users, and achieve commitment from core users to participate in the Stage 2 pilot programs. PG stage outcomes include the pilot program plan, public involvement plan, and evaluation framework. Stage 2 will implement the pilot programs and compare the effectiveness of the labor force-centered and the employer-centered mobility solutions at addressing the spatial mismatch problem. Successful implementation and evaluation of the pilot programs will help to determine (1) whether UCMS can solve spatial mismatch, and (2) whether a labor force-centered or employer-centered strategy works better.<br/><br/>This project is in response to Track A – CIVIC Innovation Challenge - Communities and Mobility a collaboration with NSF and the Department of Energy.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of this Planning Grant are to develop pilot models of User-Centered Mobility Solutions (UCMS), which integrate new mobility technologies (e.g., microtransit) to directly address the mobility needs of two groups of core users—the labor force and employers—of the new services. The proposed pilot is subsequently funded by the NSF CIVIC Full Award, which allows the comparison of the effectiveness of the labor force-centered and employer-centered mobility services at addressing a spatial mismatch between labor force living in marginalized inner-city neighborhoods and growing jobs in a suburban employment center in the Milwaukee region.

Intellectual Merit 

The proposed UCMS models have the potential to transform existing mobility service delivery by adopting a fundamentally different approach that is bottom-up—focusing on the core users and their respective needs—and goal-oriented—solving a spatial mismatch problem that has long been recognized but failed to be solved. Second, the proposed pilot and evaluation framework will provide empirical evidence whether equity-focused services can narrow the gap between advancements in mobility technologies and technology adoption among marginalized communities. Third, the research-centered pilot experiments will facilitate scientific discovery that advances understanding of how the two models achieve a diverse set of goals. 

Broader Impacts

UCMS can address significant travel disparities experienced by racial/ethnic minorities and others who have lower incomes and may have difficulty affording reliable automobiles. Improving access to jobs will give labor forces greater flexibility to search for jobs, leading to higher wages, better working conditions, and better socioeconomic prospects. With affordable and reliable UCMS, employers can expect greater recruitment and retention rates and thus higher productivity, which has a direct impact on the nation’s economy. The results from this project will be integrated into undergraduate- and graduate-level courses in the urban planning and civil engineering programs. Research publications will be disseminated through prominent academic journals, academic conferences, the team’s institutional websites and social media sites, UCMS websites, and professional organization networks. Successful engagement activities can build and maintain community trust with research universities and private and public sectors. 

 


Last Modified: 07/21/2022
Modified by: Lingqian Hu
